title: The Trump-Biden Debate
desc:
In case you missed it...

The post The Trump-Biden Debate appeared first on Wait But Why.
summary_en: The first Trump-Biden debate transcript is provided, with the candidates discussing various topics including the Supreme Court, healthcare, and the COVID-19 pandemic. The debate discussion is heated and contentious.
summary_zh: 第一次特朗普-拜登辩论内容：国务院大丈гіਾ尔花蓮被特朗普提名称謀取 replacement late Ruth Bader Ginsburg、健康保障和中共病毒疫情的辩论。这场辩论的发ън想有点火辣。
best_quote_en: "I’m cutting drug prices. Insulin is like water."
best_quote_zh: "（提取自：我正在减少药品价格。短非是水。）"

title: Daniel Kahneman: Algorithms Make Better Decisions Than You [The Knowledge Project Ep. #238]
desc:
Daniel Kahneman (1934 to 2024) won the Nobel Prize for proving we’re not as rational as we think. We discuss how to think clearly in a world full of noise, the invisible forces that cloud our judgement, and why more information doesn’t equal better thinking. Kahneman also reveals the mental model he discovered at 22 that still guides elite …

The post Daniel Kahneman: Algorithms Make Better Decisions Than You [The Knowledge Project Ep. #238] appeared first on Farnam Street.
summary_en: The interview discusses how Daniel Kahneman, a Nobel laureate, explains the importance of delaying intuition, loss aversion, and the impact of rules and facts on decision-making. He also touches on the Julia Fallacy, wanting the score over the prize, behavior being situational rather than personality, and beliefs being formed by trusted people.
summary_zh: 该交话谈论丹尼尔·荤麦诺安（дан尼尔·荤麦诺安，获得nobel奖）explain授权延迟直觉，损失抗性和规则、事实对决策的影响。他还谈论了要求分数相反于获胜 dividends，行为是环境而不是个性，以及信念通常是由受尊重的人形成的。
best_quote_zh: 在让直觉rea作 appeared后等一下

title: [Outliers] Jimmy Pattison: Building a $16B Empire Without Connections, Capital, or Credentials [The Knowledge Project Ep. #235]
desc:
At 96 years old, Jimmy Pattison still runs his $16 billion empire personally. He’s built it over 63 years without outside capital or a college degree. He owns 100% of car dealerships, billboards, radio stations—even Ripley’s Believe It or Not—with a philosophy of: “No partners, no shareholders, no relatives.” This episode is based on Jimmy: …

The post [Outliers] Jimmy Pattison: Building a $16B Empire Without Connections, Capital, or Credentials [The Knowledge Project Ep. #235] appeared first on Farnam Street.
summary_en: At 96, Jimmy Pattison still runs a $16 billion empire he built without outside capital, a college degree, or partners. The article shares lessons from Pattison's biography, including the importance of reputation, bouncing back from failures, and keeping focus on cash flow.
summary_zh: 96岁的Jimmy Pattison每天都在个人运营一个16亿美元的帝国，这个帝国于1929年的庞大父亲的汽车деaler shop破产后 Meanwhile, Jimmy watch his father repaid every penny by working as a mechanic and laborer for 25 years, instead of filing for bankruptcy. The article summarizes brilliant strategies from Pattison's biography, such as the significance of reputation, bouncing back from adversity, and the importance of cash flow.
best_quote_en: Reputation is trust, and trust takes decades to build, seconds to destroy.
best_quote_zh: 信任是信解，信解需要多年才建立，只需要几秒才破灭。

title: Superlinear Returns
summary_en: The article discusses the concept of superlinear returns, a phenomenon where the rewards for performance exceed the initial investment. It highlights two fundamental causes: exponential growth and thresholds. Examples given include growing bacterial cultures, startups, fame, and power. The article emphasizes the importance of understanding superlinear returns for those who are ambitious.
summary_zh: 文章讨论了超线性回报的概念，这是指性能 rewards 超过了初始投资。它解释了两个基本原因：指数增长和阈值。给出了 inclusion  namely growing bacterial cultures, startups, fame, 和 力量 的示例。文章强调理解超线性回报对有志于成功的人尤其重要。
best_quote_en: In all of these, the rich get richer.
best_quote_zh: 在所有这些方面，富人会更 wealthy。

title: How to Do Great Work
summary_en: The article offers a recipe for doing great work, stressing the importance of passion, curiosity, and boldness in choosing a field, learning its frontier, noticing gaps, and exploring promising ones. It encourages personal projects, outlier ideas, and a deep interest in work.
summary_zh: 文章在介绍如何做出伟大成就的方法时强调了选择领域、学习其前沿、探索itz Hierarchy金字塔的口袋以及Status Quo，有期限的学习和卥章思维是成功的关键。它鼓励个人项目、极外焦点和对工作的深保 сы中性.
best_quote_en: The three most powerful motives are curiosity, delight, and the desire to do something impressive.
best_quote_zh: 素质、喜欢和릭戎金的欲望是最强大的动力

title: How to Get New Ideas
summary_en: The article discusses a personal view on generating new ideas by emphasizing the importance of noticing anomalies or gaps in knowledge, particularly in frontier areas. This can lead to the discovery of whole new trends or concepts.
summary_zh: 文章提出了个人对新思想生成的看法，强调要注意异常或知识空白，尤其是在前沿领域。这有可能导致发现新的分支走法。
best_quote_en: The best place to look for anomalies is at the frontiers of knowledge.
best_quote_zh: 最好的异常发现地点是知识的前沿。

title: The Need to Read
summary_en: The article argues that reading and writing are closely interconnected and essential for discovery and understanding. Reading not only teaches you about a topic, but also how to write, and vice versa. Writing helps in exploring new ideas and solving complex, ill-defined problems. Therefore, being good at reading and writing is crucial.
summary_zh: 文章在讨论阅读和写作之间的密切关联和重要性方面，表示阅读不仅教导您学习某一主题，还带有如何写作的教导功能，并相反。写作帮助人们探索新想法并解决复杂、不明确的问题。因此，计划良好的阅读和写作是必备的。
best_quote_en: You can't think well without writing well, and you can't write well without reading well.
best_quote_zh: 你不能合理地思考而不会写好，也不能写好而不会读好。

title: What You (Want to)* Want
summary_en: The article discusses the paradox between predictable physical behavior and the feeling of free will, using a series of modified statements to approach the answer. It's suggested that while individuals can control their actions, their desires or higher-order desires may not always be controllable.
summary_zh: 文章提供了解决物质行为统atively的感觉自由象异常的解题方法，通过修订一系列的断言逐渐接近答案。答案建议是，虽然人们可以控制行动，但他们的愿望或更高阶的愿望可能是不可控的。
best_quote_en: You can do what you want, but there's some statement of the form 'you can't (want to)* want what you want' that's true.
best_quote_zh: 你可以做自己想要做的事，但有些形式为‘你无法(想要)*想要自己想要的事’的陈述是正确的。
